name: Eurasian Spoonbill
description: It is entirely white, with a dark beak and legs. During breeding season, it has a yellowish chest spot and elongated head feathers. In flight, it holds its neck extended like storks.
spread_note: Breeds in Eurasia from Spain to Japan (a few pairs in the Czech Republic) and northern Africa. Winters in tropical regions of Africa and Asia, sometimes in the Mediterranean.
food_note: Aquatic invertebrates (mollusks, crustaceans, worms) and small vertebrates
image_alt: Eurasian Spoonbill, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 69–82 cm; tail length 11–13 cm; wingspan 115–135 cm; weight 0.8–2 kg
attractions: It nests in colonies, building nests from branches, twigs, leaves, and grass, either in trees or reeds. Its distinctively shaped beak, up to 23 cm long, probes shallow water and soft mud. The oldest ringed individual was 28 years old.
breeding: The first Eurasian spoonbills were acquired from the wild in 1995—two females, one dying in 2013, the other still at the zoo. Later, birds came from zoos in Mulhouse, Berlin, Ohrady, and Bojnice. Since 2000, when the first chicks were raised, they have bred regularly.
